misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Loop-local accumulator resets (misunderstanding variable scope and lifetime)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that declaring the sum variable inside the loop is a good way to keep a 'running sum', and that the value will effectively carry across iterations until the end when it is printed.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, a local variable declared inside a loop body is re-created and re-initialized on every iteration. Setting `int sumOfEvenNumbers = 0;` inside the loop resets the sum each time, so it cannot accumulate across all 5 inputs. To accumulate, the sum must be declared outside the loop and updated within it.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the program prints only the last even number read (or 0 if the last number is odd), not the sum of all even inputs.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: End-of-loop printing assumes computed result is still available (misunderstanding accumulation vs last-iteration state)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that printing on the last iteration (`inputCounter == 4`) will output the total sum from all previous iterations.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Printing on the last iteration only prints whatever value exists in that iteration’s variables. Since `sumOfEvenNumbers` is local to the loop body and reset each iteration, the last iteration’s value is not the total. Even if the variable were correctly scoped, printing inside the loop based on the counter is an indirect approach; the conceptual issue is assuming the last iteration 'contains' the whole computation automatically.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output in typical cases (e.g., input `3 8 2 7 4` prints `4` instead of `14`).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that declaring a variable inside a loop will preserve its value across loop iterations, or that the variable will somehow accumulate values even though it is re-declared and re-initialized to 0 each iteration.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, variables declared inside a loop block are local to that block and are created anew on each iteration. When `int sumOfEvenNumbers = 0;` is executed in each iteration, a fresh variable is created initialized to 0. The variable from the previous iteration is destroyed and inaccessible. The student appears to believe the variable persists or accumulates across iterations, but the re-declaration and re-initialization to 0 means each iteration starts fresh. The final print statement only sees the sum from the last iteration (which will be at most one number's value, since only one even number is checked per iteration).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program will produce incorrect output. For the sample input '3 8 2 7 4', it will print only the last even number found (4) instead of the sum of all even numbers (14). More generally, it prints only the value of the last even number encountered, or 0 if the last number is odd.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that by placing the sum variable inside the loop, it will magically persist and accumulate across iterations, or that re-initializing it to 0 on each iteration is acceptable because the loop 'controls' the variable freshly each time.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The accumulator pattern requires a variable to be declared OUTSIDE the loop so that it persists across all iterations. By declaring `sumOfEvenNumbers` inside the loop and reinitializing it to 0 on each iteration, the student has broken the accumulation mechanism. Each iteration resets the sum to 0, so no accumulation occurs. The comments suggest the student intended to accumulate ('running sum'), but the code structure prevents this.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The output will be incorrect. Instead of summing all even numbers across all 5 inputs, only the last even number (or 0) is printed.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that a variable declared and initialized inside a loop body can still function as an accumulator for values across multiple iterations. They specifically think that declaring it inside the loop keeps it 'controlled' and 'fresh' while still expecting the final iteration to hold the cumulative sum of all previous iterations.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, variables declared within a loop block are local to that specific iteration. When the loop repeats, the variable is re-initialized (in this case, reset to 0), and any value stored from the previous iteration is lost. For a variable to accumulate data across iterations, it must be declared in a scope that outlives the loop (i.e., before the loop starts).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that declaring `sumOfEvenNumbers` inside the loop is a good way to keep a "running sum" and that the value will somehow represent the total after all 5 inputs, even though it is reset each iteration.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, a local variable declared inside a loop body is re-created (re-initialized) on every iteration. An accumulator must be declared outside the loop so its value persists across iterations. Resetting it to 0 each time prevents accumulation of previous even numbers.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (only the last iteration’s contribution is printed; often prints 0 unless the 5th number is even).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Loop-End Handling Confusion (Printing inside the loop)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes printing the sum when `inputCounter == 4` (inside the loop) will print the final total, even though the variable being printed is only the current iteration’s local value.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Printing at the last iteration can work only if the accumulator correctly persists across iterations. Here, because the sum variable is local to each iteration, printing at the last iteration prints only that iteration’s computed value, not an accumulated total. Generally, the total should be printed after the loop using an accumulator declared outside the loop.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (final print reflects only last iteration’s sum value, not total).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Block-Scoped Variable Persistence Across Loop Iterations
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that declaring a variable inside the loop body makes it 'fresh and controlled' for each iteration, but also that the variable's value somehow persists or is accessible across subsequent iterations. They expect that all even numbers encountered throughout the loop will accumulate in the same sum variable, which they can print on the final iteration.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, a variable declared inside a block (including a loop body) is scoped to that block only. Each iteration creates a brand new variable that shadows any identically named variable from previous iterations. The variable ceases to exist at the end of that iteration. The student conflates declaring a variable 'inside the loop' with it being somehow persistent across iterations. They cannot access `sumOfEvenNumbers` from iteration 1 in iteration 4—each iteration has its own independent variable that is born and dies with that iteration.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program prints only the last even number found (4) instead of the sum of all even numbers (14). This is because `sumOfEvenNumbers` is reset to 0 at the start of each iteration, so only the contribution from the final iteration (when inputCounter == 4) is available when the print statement executes.

evidence.code_snippet:
// Declare the sum variable inside the loop so it is fresh and controlled each time
            int sumOfEvenNumbers = 0;

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that declaring and initializing a variable inside a loop allows it to be 'fresh' for each iteration while still being able to accumulate a total to be printed at the end of the loop's execution. They think the variable maintains its state across iterations despite the explicit re-assignment to zero at the start of the block.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, a variable declared and initialized inside a loop body has block scope and is re-created and re-assigned its initial value every time the loop body executes. To maintain state across iterations (the accumulator pattern), the variable must be declared and initialized outside the loop scope.

evidence.code_snippet: if (inputCounter == 4) { System.out.println("Sum of even numbers: " + sumOfEvenNumbers); }
